Now scientists have been talking about hollow Earth for at least 400 years now.

No, there were scientists who were talking about it some 400 years ago.  But they stopped talking about it in 1774 when the Earth's mean density was measured in the Sheehalion experiment.  Simply put, the point of that experiment was to measure the gravitational attraction of a mountain of known composition and volume compared to that of the Earth by looking at how much a pendulum was deflected by the mountain's gravitational pull.  According to this experiment, the Earth had a mean density of 4,500 kilograms per cubic meter.  This is lower than the currently accepted value of 5,515, but still high enough to rule out the Earth being hollow.
One of the oldest hollow Earth hypotheses comes from a man named Edmund Halley.
And you'll notice that he lived before 1774.
It's also rumored that prolific mathematician, Leonard Euler, proposed a hollow Earth model where the core is kind of like a miniature sun.
Yes, it's rumored.  Euler never wrote anything about it, although supposedly he did use the idea of a hollow Earth in a thought experiment, so that could be where the rumor got started.
And what many of these theories have in common was that some sort of entrance to these realms existed at our Earth's poles in Antarctica and the Arctic.
Also falsified by the empirical fact that we've looked and they're not there.

We all know what science tells us about the internal structure of the planet.  But it's important to question how we came to this conclusion.

The same way we come to any conclusion in science.  We use our available understanding to formulate a hypothesis which makes an empirically falsifiable prediction.  We test that hypothesis by subjecting it to an experiment that would falsify it should the result fail to meet the prediction.  If the hypothesis survives the test, this is regarded as evidence in favor of the hypothesis.  If it doesn't, then the hypothesis is modified to take the result into account and we look for a new way to test the modified version.  Either way, we update our available knowledge accordingly.  This method is used to build up entire predictive frameworks that we call theories.  And while this is all inductive and therefore can never give us 100% certainty, a theory can easily become so successful at making good predictions that we cannot realistically expect it to ever be overturned in its entirety.  The knowledge we have of the interior of the Earth is on that level.  There may be details we're wrong about, but that's it.
As we said earlier, we've only ever observed 8 miles deep into the Earth.
False.  We've observed all the way down to the core.  We haven't been there, but there are other ways to observe things than to physically be there and see it directly with your eyes.
